a b s t r a c t
During the past decade, the limitation of petroleum based polymers, the high price of oil, and the environmental concern were attracted the attention of researchers to develop biobased polymers. The composition of different biopolymers and the reinforcement with nano filler are common methods to improve the drawbacks of biopolymers. In this study whey protein isolate/pullulan (WPI/PUL) films contain 1%, 3%, and 5% (w/w) nano-SiO2 (NS) were prepared by a casting method. Tensile strength of nanocomposite films increased after increasing NS content, but elongation at break decreased, simultaneously. Water absorption, moisture content, solubility in water improved in the wake of increasing NS content because NS increase the cohesiveness of the polymer matrix and improved the barrier and water resistance properties of the films. water vapor permeability of film specimens decreased by increasing NS content. Uniform distribution of NS into polymer matrix was confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). XRD pattern and thermal analysis revealed increasing crystallinity and increasing Tg of film specimens with increasing NS content, respectively. According to our result WPI/PUL/NS films possess potential to be used as environment friendly packaging films to improve shelf life of food and can be used as promising alternative to petroleum based packaging films.

. Introduction
Development of biopolymers has been increased over the past ecade. This development is attributed to environmental conerns, the limitation of petroleum resources, and the oil price 1,2]. Although the complete substitution of petroleum-based poly-
ers is impossible, but partial substitution of petroleum-based olymers by biopolymers is conceivable. The sensitivity of the iopolymers to water, the incommensurate barrier properties, and he mechanical weakness of the biopolymers are the main reaons for paying attention to biopolymer modification. Combination f polysaccharides-proteins [3,4], adding plasticizers [5,6], develpment of bionanocomposites [1], and -irradiation [7] are the ommon modification methods of biopolymers.
Biopolymers are considered as promising materials because hey are abundant cost effective end products. Whey protein isolate WPI) is one of the abundant by-products in dairy factories and it

causes environmental obstacles. WPI contains highly bio available essential amino acids [8]. WPI based biopolymers form a transparent and flexible film with fairly good functional properties [9,10].
Pullulan (PUL) is a microbial polysaccharide which is produces by Aureobasidium pullulans in starch and sugar cultures. PUL is utilized in low calorie foods, adhesive binders, thickeners, and encapsulating agents [11]. Recently, PUL has attracted an interest to be used as filmogenic material in food packaging. PUL film is transparent, low oil, and oxygen permeable [12,13].
The common disadvantages of most of biopolymers are sensitivity to water, poor mechanical properties, and water vapor barrier properties [1,14]. One of the recommended modification methods is blending polysaccharides and proteins [3,15]. Furthermore, mixing the biopolymer with nano particles has been the center of attention as a modification method of biopolymers [1,3,16]. High surface area and homogenous dispersion of the nano particles in polymer matrix bring about outstanding properties compared to conventional micro composites [17].
Nano-SiO2 (NS), amorphous powder with tridimensional structure, was produced from silicon oxide with SiO2−x formulation that x ranges from 0.4 to 0.8 [18]. The striking feature of NS i.e. small size,

In many parts of the world, iO2 is the major constituent of sand [21]. Almost all of nanopartiles show some side effects on humane body. Nevertheless, there s less concern about eco-pollution of NS [21].
The main purpose of the current study was to improve water ensibility, permeability, visual drawback, and mechanical properies of WPI and PUL by composition. Furthermore, the functional roperty of WPI/PUL films was intensified with NS. The characterzation of WPI/PUL/NS films was investigated by XRD, SEM, and ifferential scanning calorimetry (DSC).
. Materials and methods
.1. Material
WPI contain over 85% protein was purchased from (Arla Food ngredient, Denmark), PUL with molecular weight 10,000–14,000
as provided from Hayashibara (Hayashibara Co., Ltd., Japan), and S was purchased from TECNAN (tecnologia Navarra de Nanoprouctos S.L, Spain). The analytical grade chemicals, including sodium hloride (NaCl), calcium chloride (CaCl2) and calcium nitrite Ca(NO2)2), were purchased from Merck (Merck Co., Germany).
.2. Film preparation
5 g WPI was dissolved in 100 ml distilled water, heated at 90 ◦C or 30 min, and stirred with magnetic stirrer. Then 5 g PUL was disolved in 100 ml distilled water and mixed with WPI solution (1:1) /w. After wards 30% w/w (dry base) glycerol was added as plasicizer into the solution. Three NS suspensions were prepared by ltrasonic bath at ambient temperature for 1 h so that the concenration of NS in WPI/PUL solution was 1%, 3% and 5% w/w (dry base). he solution was subsequently casted onto Teflon plates (15 cm iameter) and dried for 48 h at 25 ◦C in oven and room relative umidity. All the film specimens were conditioned inside desicators containing a saturated calcium nitrite solution to ensure
relative humidity of 55% at 25 ± 1 ◦C for 48 h. The conditioned lms were used for other analysis. All samples were prepared in
riplicates.
.3. Thickness
The thickness of specimens was measured by a hand-held icrometer with an accuracy of 0.01 mm at least in 8 random posi-
ions for each film.
.4. Mechanical properties
Mechanical properties of films were determined by material esting machine (Testometric – M350 – 10CT, England) according o ASTM D882 [22]. Initial grips separation and cross head speed ere set to 50 mm and 10 mm/min, respectively. Tensile strength TS) and elongation at break (EB) were calculated by Eqs. (1) and 2), respectively.

2.5. Moisture content
Moisture content (MC) of the film specimens were determined by the weight of the samples before (m1) and after (m2) oven drying at 105 ◦C (Eq. (3)).
MC = m1 − m2 m2 × 100 (3)
2.6. Solubility in water
Solubility in water (SW) was defined as the ratio of the water-soluble dry matter of film that is dissolved after immersion in distilled water. SW of the film specimens was measured according to the method of Shahabi-Ghahfarrokhi et al. [1]. The 20 mm×20 mm film specimens were dried at 105 ◦C, and weighed (m3). Then dried samples were immersed into 50 ml of distilled water for 6 h. The remaining films were dried at 105 ◦C and weighed (m4). SW was calculated by Eq. (4). SW = m3 − m4 m4 × 100 (4)
2.7. Moisture absorption
Moisture absorption (MA) was measured according to the method of Almasi et al. [23]. In brief, the dried sheets of 20×20 mm2 were first conditioned at 0% RH (prepared by dried calcium sulphate) for 24 h. After weighing (m5), they were conditioned in a desiccators containing a saturated calcium-nitrite solution at 25 ◦C to ensure a relative humidity of 55%. The specimen was weighed at desired intervals until an equilibrium state was reached (m6). The moisture absorption of the specimen was calculated via Eq. (5).
MA = m6 − m5 m5 × 100 (5)
2.8. Water vapor permeability
Water vapor permeability (WVP) was determined gravimetrically according to ASTM method E96-95 [24]. The films were fixed on the top of glass cup containing of dehydrated calcium chloride and sealed with paraffin. Cups were placed in a desiccators containing saturated solution of sodium chloride, and weighed with 1 hour interval for 24 h at 25 ◦C. The slope (S) of time–weight curve was calculated by linear regression model (R2 ≥ 0.986). Water vapor transition rate (WVTR) and WVP were calculated by Eqs. (6) and (7), respectively.

.12. Differential scanning calorimetry
Thermal properties of specimens were measured by DSC (METLER TOLEDO, Switzerland) according to ASTM standard method 3418-08 [27]. A film specimen of approximately 6 mg was cut and laced into a pan of the DSC equipment, and hermetically sealed. An mpty pan was used as reference. The temperature program was xed from −50 ◦C to 250 ◦C at a heating rate of 20 ◦C/min. The glassransition temperatures (Tg) of the different films were determined rom the resulting thermo grams as the midpoint temperature of a tep-down shift in baseline. The melting point (Tm) was calculated s the temperature where the peak of the endothermic occurred. ll these properties were determined in duplicate and the results ere averaged.
.13. Scanning electron microscopy
The morphology of the surface and the cross-section of films ere observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-
EM) KYKY-EM3200 (KYKY, China) with the accelerating beam at voltage of 25 kV. The film specimens were sputtered with a thin ayer of gold using a KYKY-SBC-12 sputter coater (KYKY, China).
.14. Statistical analysis
Statistics on a completely randomized design were performed ith the analysis of variance (ANOVA) procedure using SPSS softare (Version 20; SPSS Inc., USA). Duncan’s multiple range tests ere used to compare the differences among the mean values of lm specimens’ properties at level of 0.05.
. Result and discussion
.1. SEM micrographs
Fig. 1 shows the morphological properties of the surface and ross section of WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite films. he surface of WPI/PUL film was smooth and homogenous. Some mall circular particles were observed on the surface of the
iological Macromolecules 86 (2016) 139–144 141
nanocomposite films (Fig. 1S). The number of the particles and surface roughness were amplified after increasing NS content. Despite aggregation of NS particles on the surface, no NS aggregation was observed in cross-section micrograph of the specimens (Fig. 1C). Uniform distribution of NS in polymer matrix, C O Si chemical bond, the plenty of hydrogen bonds between PUL/WPI hydroxyl groups, and oxygen atoms in the NS brought about strong interfacial bindings between nanocomposite components [1,18,23]. According to TECNAN catalog, the bulk density of NS is less than 0.10 g/cm2. It seems the porous structure of NS brought about the movement of aggregated NS to film surface. The compact and smooth microstructure of the specimens may be the consequence of the binding. Our result was consistent with our previous research [18].
3.2. Transparency and color
Transparency of the film is a main factor for the customer to see clearly through packaging material. The transparency and color of WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite films were exhibited in Table 1. There was no significant difference between the transparencies of the WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposites. This is attributed to good miscibility of NS in the nanocomposite. Furthermore, the size of nano particles was less than the wavelength of visible light. Thus, the light could be passed through the film and exhibit the transparency of the specimens [2].
Table 1 presents the values of hunter color (L, a, and b), E, YI, and WI of WPI/PUL films as a function of NS concentration. However, there was no significant difference between red-green factor (a), of films before and after NS incorporation. But yellowblue factor (b) and yellow index (YI) increased with increasing NS content. White index (WI) decreased as a result of increasing NS concentration. Furthermore, there were no significant difference between lightness value (L) of WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite films up to (3 wt%), but L value decreased at higher NS loading fraction (5 wt%), significantly.
3.3. Moisture content, moisture absorption, and solubility in water
Hydrogen bonds, hydrophilic interaction, ionic bonds and hygroscopic properties of PUL bring about high solubility of WPI/PUL films. The effect of NS on MC, MA, and SW of the films was shown in Table 2. The SW of the WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposites was decreased from 87.46% to 71.98% as a result of increasing NS content up to 5%. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds between NS and WPI/PUL brought about the formation of network structure, and increased the cohesiveness of the polymer matrix. As a result, NS improved the barrier and water resistance properties of the films [18,28].
Increasing NS content (5 wt%) in the bionanocomposites decreased MC and MA up to 12.05% and 10.44%, respectively. It seems that the interaction between biopolymer and NS reduced the occupied void volume of polymer matrix and NS [29]. The strong formed structure and interaction between biopolymers and NS reduced the diffusion of water molecules into nanocomposites and decreased the MA of them [23].
3.4. Water vapor permeability
WVP is often used to study the moisture transport through the film and is of interest in almost all research into the characterization of biopolymers because it is a key factor in food packaging to support food against water adsorption and desorption [1]. WVP of WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite films were explained in Table 2. WVP of WPI/PUL film decreased around 33% because of the increase of NS content up to 5%. As Shown in (Fig. 1C), the

.5. Mechanical properties
TS and EB of neat WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite lms were shown in Table 3. The TS of specimens was positively
affected by NS contents of 1 and 3%, reaching 3.51 ± 1.71 MPa, but the corresponding value of nanocomposite containing 5% NS dropped to 3.07 ± 1.16 MPa. The composite system could be depicted by three-dimensional bond matrix constituted with metal oxide nano particle, WPI, and PUL chains. There was no significant difference between EB of WPI/PUL/NS omposite films after increasing the NS content up to 3%, but the orresponding value of nanocomposite containing 5% NS drastially dropped to 122.01 ± 6.89%. Previous researchers showed that ncreasing TS and decreasing EB of nanocomposite films had been ue to interfacial interactions between NS and biopolymer [31]. fter optimum nano particle content, the TS and EB of nanocomosite was negatively affected by increasing nano particle content s results of nano particle aggregation and local stress [1,29].
.6. XRD
Fig. 2 shows XRD pattern and CD of WPI/PUL and its anocomposite films. The broad and weak peak located at = 12.30◦confirmed the amorphous structure of NS [32,33]. CD f film specimen was calculated according to the main peak. CD f the WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite increased up to 3% NS conent. Because of aggregation NS at high content (5%), WPI and PUL
olecules interpenetrate and intertwine with each other, disturbng the arrangement regularity among WPI, PUL, and NS molecules, nd thus decreasing the crystallinity of WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposte [34].
.7. DSC
Fig. 3 shows DSC thermogram, glass transition temperature Tg), and melting temperature (Tm) of WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS anocomposites with different NS content. The Tg is the tempera-
f WPI/PUL and WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposites.
ture at which the material undergoes a structural transition from an amorphous solid state (glassy state) to a more viscous rubbery state of nanocomposites. Below Tg, films are rigid and brittle, whereas above Tg they become flexible and pliable [34]. The Tg of WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposites increased drastically to 34.06 ◦C, but at a high NS content (5%), the Tg gradually deteriorated and reached to 27.09 ◦C. Increasing intermolecular interaction between silanol groups (Si–OH) in NS and WPI/PUL chains decreased the mobility of WPI/PUL/NS 3% polymer [34,35]. It brought about an augmentation of Tg [1,35]. On the other hand, at high NS content (5%), aggregated NS increased the mobility of polymer chain by ball bearing effect and decreased Tg [1].
The melting point is a measure of the energy required to disrupt the crystal lattice. The effective factors on Tm are intermolecular forces, molecular symmetry, and conformational degree of free volume of a molecule [36]. As shown in Fig. 3, Tm of the WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposites was independent of NS content. Molecular motion and intermolecular hydrogen bonding are contradictory effective parameters on melting point [36]. Hence, it seems the independence of melting point from NS content was owing to the equality of these two factors.
4. Conclusion
According to the results, the TS of the nanocomposite was increased whereas, the EB decreased, simultaneously. NS as a nano filler improved the water sensibility and WVP of the WPI/PUL/NS nanocomposite films without leaving any side effect on visual properties and transparency of the film specimens. Thermal properties of WPI/PUL/NS were NS content-dependent. It seems the mentioned properties were affected by distribution of NS in WPI/PUL

metadata.abstractText: During the past decade, the limitation of petroleum based polymers, the high price of oil, and the environmental concern were attracted the attention of researchers to develop biobased polymers. The composition of different biopolymers and the reinforcement with nano filler are common methods to improve the drawbacks of biopolymers. In this study whey protein isolate/pullulan (WPI/PUL) films contain 1%, 3%, and 5% (w/w) nano-SiO2 (NS) were prepared by a casting method. Tensile strength of nanocomposite films increased after increasing NS content, but elongation at break decreased, simultaneously. Water absorption, moisture content, solubility in water improved in the wake of increasing NS content because NS increase the cohesiveness of the polymer matrix and improved the barrier and water resistance properties of the films. water vapor permeability of film specimens decreased by increasing NS content. Uniform distribution of NS into polymer matrix was confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). XRD pattern and thermal analysis revealed increasing crystallinity and increasing Tg of film specimens with increasing NS content, respectively. According to our result WPI/PUL/NS films possess potential to be used as environment friendly packaging films to improve shelf life of food and can be used as promising alternative to petroleum based packaging films. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
